awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Integrating two different roles of the proton-pumping pyrophosphatase in the regulation and efficiency of carbon utilization and transport in planta
awd_abstract_narration:
Plant productivity is determined in large part by the partitioning of reduced carbon (sugar) between the sites of production (photosynthetic tissues) and the sites of utilization (growing tissues such as roots and young leaves, etc). To judiciously engineer increased yield of crop plants, a better understanding of the regulation and efficiency of sugar transport throughout the plant is required. Work by the principal investigators and others has shown that the up-regulation of proton-pyrophosphatases (H+-PPases) results in enhanced root and shoot growth and increased photosynthetic output. The principal investigators hypothesize that plant H+-PPases play a crucial role in regulating sucrose synthesis, partitioning and utilization.  The  hypotheses will be tested using a combination of genetic, metabolomic, molecular biological, and ultra-structural approaches. The research will shed light not only on the fundamental physiological subject of carbon utilization and transport, but also has  potential downstream applications since increased H+-PPase activity enhances plant biomass, nutrient uptake capacities, and stress tolerance. With growing populations, decreasing arable land, and a national desire to exploit plants for biofuels, understanding the role of H+-PPases in plant growth could be transformative. 

The outcomes of this project will be made available to the scientific community through timely publication and by the participation of the principal investigators in their undergraduate and graduate education programs.  The professional development of undergraduate and graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows will occur at the interface of genetics, physiology, cell biology and cutting-edge metabolomics. The project participants will work together with the Arizona State University "Ask a Biologist" program to develop topical content on biomass for fuel and how it relates to the movement of energy throughout biological systems.

por.por_cntn:
Plant productivity is determined in large part by the partitioning of metabolites between the sites of production and the sites of utilization. We showed that proton pumping pyrophosphatases (H+PPases) enhance many processes including general growth (biomass accumulation), nutrient acquisition, photosynthetic CO2 fixation, and stress responses.  Intellectual Merit: We hypothesized that H+PPases participate in phloem loading and metabolite transport by localizing to the plasma membrane of phloem cells and utilizing the proton motive force (pmf) to create pyrophosphate (PPi) rather than hydrolyzing it. Additional PPi in the phloem promotes sucrose oxidation and ATP synthesis, which the plasma membrane ATPase in turn uses to create more pmf.  To support these hypotheses, we conducted immunohistochemical studies to show that the H+PPase protein, AVP1, localized to phloem companion cells of leaf vasculature. We generated transgenic Arabidopsis thaliana plants with phloem-specific AVP1 overexpression from the Commelina yellow mottle virus promoter (COYMVpro::AVP1) and compared these to plants with ubiquitous AVP1 overexpression using a 35Spro::AVP1 cassette. Plants with both ubiquitous and companion cell-specific overexpression demonstrated enhanced photosynthesis and accumulated more biomass in shoot and root systems. Isotopic 14C-labeling experiments supported enhanced photosynthesis and also demonstrated greater phloem loading, phloem transport, and phloem-mediated metabolite delivery to heterotrophic sink organs. Both COYMVpro::AVP1 and 35Spro::AVP1 plants displayed rhizosphere acidification to benefit uptake of essential nutrients, and increased expression of genes encoding nutrient uptake systems for potassium, nitrate, and phosphate.  Since the results obtained with constitutive and companion cell-specific promoters were very similar, the growth enhancements mediated by AVP1 overexpression can be attributed to its role in phloem companion cells. By contrast, phloem-specific AVP1 knockdown (pCoYMV::RNAi-AVP1) resulted in stunted seedlings suggesting a transport deficiency.  This phenotype was partially rescued by growth in the presence of exogenous sucrose, further suggesting a deficiency in source-to-sink metabolite transport.  Collectively, these results supports the model for H+PPases localizing to the plasma membrane and functioning as a PPi synthase in the phloem by arguing that the increases in biomass observed with AVP1 overexpression derive from improved phloem loading and transport. The collective results also argue that the PPi synthase activity of AVP1 in companion cells is critical for the maintenance of pyrophosphate homeostasis required for phloem function.  Broader Impacts: This research shed light on a fundamental physiological subject and had a strong applied component: To judiciously engineer increased yield of crop plants, a better understanding of the regulation and efficiency of nutrient and metabolite utilization and transport is required.  During the course of this research, we trained high school, undergraduate, and graduate students in experimental design, plant physiology, molecular biology and metabolic analysis. There was also training for graduate students and postdoctoral scholars with large datasets from metabolomics (analytical quantitation of primary metabolites present in the tissues) and transcriptomics (quantitative analysis of all genes expressed in the tissue).  Graduate students gained experience in teaching and training other junior colleagues both at the bench and in formal classroom and teaching-laboratory environments. Interactions and intellectual exchanges between the laboratories of Dr. Brian Ayre and collaborator Dr. Roberto Gaxiola at Arizona State University broadened the experiences and prospects for graduate students and postdoctoral scholars.  New projects in both the Ayre and Gaxiola laboratories have independently received additional funding to continue the trajectory of the fundamental and applied outcomes of this research.
